title: 109_hr4917
content: The "Protect America First Act of 2006" is the short title of this Act. It includes amendments to the Defense Production Act of 1950. The "Protect America First Act of 2006" includes amendments to the Defense Production Act of 1950, specifically regarding notification requirements to Congress for proposed mergers, acquisitions, or takeovers subject to investigation. The "Protect America First Act of 2006" mandates that the President or designee must notify Congress within one day of initiating an investigation on proposed mergers, acquisitions, or takeovers. Congress members specified in subparagraph (D) are entitled to relevant information and timely responses during the investigation process. The "Protect America First Act of 2006" requires the President or designee to inform specified members of Congress promptly about decisions made during investigations on mergers, acquisitions, or takeovers. Members include the Speaker, Minority Leader of the House, Majority, and Minority Leaders of the Senate, as well as Chairmen and Ranking Members of relevant committees. The "Protect America First Act of 2006" mandates timely notification to key members of Congress regarding decisions made in investigations on mergers, acquisitions, or takeovers. This includes specified members from various committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate. The "Protect America First Act of 2006" requires prompt notification to key members of Congress about investigations on mergers, acquisitions, or takeovers. Amendments are made to ensure confidentiality of information and technical corrections are applied to Section 721 of the Defense Production Act of 1950. The "Protect America First Act of 2006" mandates timely notification to Congress regarding mergers, acquisitions, or takeovers subject to investigation under the Defense Production Act of 1950. Effective immediately, new requirements apply to written notifications received after the enactment of this Act. The "Protect America First Act of 2006" mandates timely notification to Congress regarding mergers, acquisitions, or takeovers subject to investigation under the Defense Production Act of 1950. Congress believes that the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) should be transferred to the Department of Homeland Security, with the Secretary of Homeland Security serving as the Chairman of CFIUS.
